title: Enabling the Global Conversation in Communities

author: Reinhard Schäler, Localisation Research Centre (LRC), University of Limerick

segmentation: Thank you very much, Christian, and thank you very much for the organizers to give me the opportunity to talk to you today.
And I haven't done this in a long time, but I thought Rome would be a good place to do this, so I have to make a confession.
I'm not actually a developer.
But there is a famous Irishman, Oscar Wilde, who once said every St has a past and every Sinner has a future.
So not all is lost.
I'm going to talk to you about enabling the global conversation communities and the projects that we embarked on and.
And I've been in my current job for far too long to remember all the years.
And a lot of people say and think that you know.
Academics are a bit of a of a base because they talk about a lot of things and they create lots of solutions, but they're always looking for a problem to solve.
So I'm proud to report that we have actually, and this is where the connection between the Rosetta Foundation and the work at the localization Research Center at the University of Limerick Undersea.
NGL The Center for Next Generation localization Ireland all connect up.
And this is what I want to talk to you about today.
So the better foundation is about empowering language communities.
We set out to.
Provide free translations.
To nonprofits and about two or three years ago, and we discovered it was about business model.
No.
A lot of our colleagues in the number from the commercial provider said, you know, we are non-profit too, so you're not really doing anything new.
So we looked at what people call market localization or market driven localization and it's a 30 billion.
Dollar industry I called this mainstream and I'm stating here that it is mainly focused on short-term financial return of investment.
And there's a website, inthecompanycalledtranslator.com.
And they're very can calculate how many people with money you can reach by localising and translating into certain into a certain number of languages.
So I did that calculation and.
Turn talati can reach 90% of.
The world's customers.
Or potential customers.
By just localising into 15 languages.
So if you are commercially minded, you know this is what you should focus on.
That's the message, so it's not 990% of the world's population is 90% of the world's potential customers to people with money.
And that turns out to be around 2 billion people.
Really good why this is important is the story full of Bloomberg data.
2 examples that you might want to look at.
That are really interesting because the Storyful is a new Irish startup.
That monitors Twitter's tweets.
And they tell you if there is somewhere in the world is CEO that is about to, you know, brought to court or if there is a crisis in the government somewhere or anything that affects stock prices.
And if you find that out, Split second earlier than your competitors.
You can make a lot of money and This is why Bloomberg is interested in buying them out.
So access to information and knowledge is really crucial for money.
And This is why people are prepared to spend your 30 billion plus on this kind of business.
But you know, there's also another side to it, and you were probably wondering already.
You know what happens to the other 5 billion people that are not serviced.
So let's I've called this kind of nonmarket localization or.
You know social localization, and you know that is basically for World Peace for all the good things that you can do.
And if you look up Ethnologue, you'll find out that you know if you if you look after the remaining 5 billion people, you're probably gonna reach.
You're close to 7000 languages and 70% of the world's citizens not.
Customers citizens.
And an example, there emerged as many examples of organizations that are active in this space.
Global Voices is 1.
So there's no business case, but there's lots of motivation.
And there's lots of activity and you know.
Many, many organizations have their own translation localization community working with them there into their 10s of thousands, and they're producing 'em.
In my theory, I haven't actually been able to prove this with figures, but my theory is that you know that.
Voluntary translation community is as large if not larger as the commercial activity.
The problem.
There is that how do you connect all this content that is there with all those volunteers that are ready to help?
And.
The answer of ambience dot question about you know why not use what we've got already?
You know, so we have lots of professionals.
We have, you know, that are working with lots of content to tight schedules.

They have organized all the processes they have access to all the tools and technologies and lots of resource is the problem is that all that stuff works really well in the commercial company setting where everything is controlled and predictable and very often repetitive, repeatable.
But also proprietary very often closed and operating in a silo.
So why not to use what we've got is that when you work in this space where you work with the 5 billion, 70% of the world's population and languages, you anything can happen.
You know anybody cannot can turn up to help you with any content that you might have, and it's very, very diverse.
The process is very large and Twitter technologies that people are using are just not predictable either.
So what we need is something that is, you know, open configure.
So.
Start, let's based.
I thought that is where I W 3C standards come in.
That's where Cliff comes in and all the other good standards that we have heard about it.
But here about about during the next two days.

Our answer to this is a web based application called Soulless Match Solar stands for service oriented localization architecture solution and we have broken down into what soulless, matchon soulless productivity I'm going to talk a little bit more about sort of productivity now.
And David Philippa, colleague of mine, who's here and also.
Dave Lewis from TCD and they have set up a demo where we show the interoperability within Solus.
Productivity.
So basically, but sort of has is offers is a task stream that is self managed, intelligent and is focused on impact rather than on.
Commercial financial value.
I'll go into that a little bit more in a demonstration that I held off on slide, so I will not attempt to do this online.
Um?
So less productivity than allows people to once they have picked a task from that task stream to work.
Based on an orchestrated workflow, the components that are best of breed are available and they prefer to work with an open standards in an interoperable environment.
So we are about to.
Announce an open source project around Solas.
It was as I said, it was developed at the University of Limerick.
Everything the Center for next generation localization the CN GL.
We've just signed a first license agreement with the University.
But signed the.
And exclusive license to the Rosetta Foundation, which will, which has the right to such license?
It under an open source license.
It's kind of a funny license agreement, really.
But we will.
We will open source it and we will announce that next week at the gala conference.
So the next step then, is the deployment of with users the steering committee to help us to get solid development the right direction and support and sponsorship that we need.
So we see Solas as the tool that will connect.
This those massive amounts of content with the massive amount of people who are there to help to translate what is called non market.
But there is no content that is crucial and could be lifesaving.
In some instances, not just produce wealth for individuals.
And this project will be running and powering the translation Commons.
It's above space that we have set up that will be coordinated by the Better Foundation and that is open owned by.
Everybody cannot be commoditized, is inclusive, and has a widely shared ownership.
We are not focusing on a return of capital, but on return on social investment.
This is what it looks like, so there's a stream of.
Patient asks and that stream is ordered in preference and according to the users.

So the system is learning about the preferences of of the volunteers and presents that lists in order of the you know, the qualifications, the experience and expertise and the interests of the volunteers.

It will also provide not just information about the task on hand, but it will also provide information on the impact that that task will have on the people that will be the ultimate beneficiaries of the translations.
We have badges that the organizations can set up that will.
Allow the organization to.
To establish relationships, special relationships with specific groups of volunteers, we use tax to allow volunteers to filter the tasks cream further.
The organizations have access to a dashboard where they can look at the different projects that are.
On tremonts and they can break that down into.
Different and into the into the task stream.
So there is a project level and each.
Project that has a number of tasks associated with it.
So for example, you translate a leaflet on Wikipedia.
Good luck here.
And you want to translate that into.
A number of different languages.
It's very easy to set that up on Chairmans.
It's it organizes a basic workflow automatically for you and breaks down larger, larger projects into smaller tasks so you can have subtasks for.
Individual languages that are more likely to be picked up by volunteers who kind of shy away a little bit from very large single projects.
So.
What we need is advice.
We need the input of more people of experts.
We need some some programmers that can help us to develop solace further.
You know, there is a lot of the real intelligence in the system is will be in the in the sorting of the task stream and then matching.
The interests of translators with the specific tasks, the interest on the expertise and also the history and the performance of the translations with specific tasks.
And that is really.
That is why we called it match, because somebody step up and explained that to them they said, you know this is like a dating site for for language services and this is what it is.
It's kind of a dating site, only that you don't find your.
Another person, but you find your perfect task that suits you.
And we need some bankers in Ireland.
There at the moment, not very open to.
To talk to us.
But maybe there are other countries where you can find some finance, so thank you.
So we what we are aiming at is to empower language communities to cover the rest.
The rest of it's the five billion people that are currently not being serviced by.
The commercial language providers.
And one way of doing that is to to join the solid open source project that we will announce next week.
Thank you very much.
